pageProps.body:
Physical Systems

After much suffering, we have escaped the section where my endless onslaught of inaccuracies and awe-inspiring handwaves have attracted the murderous intent of all mathematicians around the world. Unfortunately, that does not mean the murderous intent is gone. It's going to be back with a vengeance, magnified to three times of its original size, and directed towards me by physicists rather than mathematicians (who are much more murderous, on average).

Theorem. If you're going to be murdered by someone, you'd rather be murdered by a physicist than a mathematician. This is because getting shoved into a particle accelerator and annihilated at the speed of light is a painless death, while getting stoned to death by someone hurling chalk at you is extremely painful. Don't ask me how I know.

As this section will hopefully elucidate, one of the true marvels of differential equations - second-order ones especially - is their prevalence in nature; countless physical models, from classical mechanics to electricity, rely on the same second-order DEs to tell their stories.

We begin this discussion with the simple model of a mass on a spring.

Consider an object with mass mmm, and hence weight W=mgW=mgW=mg, hanging on a spring with original length lll. Due to the application of the mass, the spring elongates to a length l+Ll + Ll+L; by Hooke's law, we know that when the extension LLL is suitably small (within the limit of proportionality), the spring experiences a restoring force Fs=−kLF_s = -kLFs​=−kL in the opposite direction to the mass's weight, where kkk is the constant of proportionality of the spring. When the spring is in equilibrium, the net force is zero and thus we have

mg=kL.mg = kL.mg=kL.

How does the system reach such an equilibrium? To answer this, we must study the displacement of the mass at time ttt from this initial position, where the spring's extension is LLL. Call this displacement u(t)u(t)u(t), or simply uuu, measured positively downwards from l+Ll+Ll+L. Thus, as shown in the figure, the length of the spring at any time is given by l+L+ul + L + ul+L+u, and hence the restoring force is given by

Fs(t)=−k(L+u(t))F_s(t) = -k(L+u(t))Fs​(t)=−k(L+u(t))

This equation is always true even if L+uL+uL+u is negative (the spring is compressed), as in that case the restoring force would be positive. The mass will always apply a constant weight W=mgW=mgW=mg downward. We must also take into account the existence of a resistive force on the mass, due to either air resistance (or resistance from other mediums), energy dissipation, friction, or some other source. We assume that this resistive force is proportional to the speed u′(t)u'(t)u′(t) of the mass, and directed upward:

Fd(t)=−γu′(t)F_d(t) = -\gamma u'(t)Fd​(t)=−γu′(t)

where γ>0\gamma > 0γ>0 is the \it damping constant\normalfont. This equation demonstrates that no matter the direction of the motion of the mass, the resistive force is always in an opposite direction. Finally, there may be an external force applied to the mass that varies with time; this may be because the spring is moving, or because of some periodic source that forces the mass to move. We call this force F(t)F(t)F(t).

To summarize, our system involves the following forces:

  1. A constant weight W=mgW=mgW=mg, directed downward.
  2. A restoring force Fs(t)=−k(L+u(t))F_s(t) = -k(L+u(t))Fs​(t)=−k(L+u(t)), originating from the tension in the spring and directed in the opposite direction to its displacement.
  3. A resistive force Fd(t)=−γu′(t)F_d(t) = -\gamma u'(t)Fd​(t)=−γu′(t), opposite in direction to the mass's motion. Note that this simple model is not always accurate and can be questioned.
  4. A variable external force F(t)F(t)F(t).

By Newton's Second Law, we have:

Fnet=ma(t)=mu′′(t)F_{net} = ma(t) = mu''(t)Fnet​=ma(t)=mu′′(t)

with FnetF_{net}Fnet​ being given by

Fnet=mg+Fs(t)+Fd(t)+F(t)=mg−k(L+u(t))−γu′(t)+F(t)F_{net} = mg + F_s(t) + F_d(t) + F(t) = mg - k(L+u(t)) - \gamma u'(t) + F(t)Fnet​=mg+Fs​(t)+Fd​(t)+F(t)=mg−k(L+u(t))−γu′(t)+F(t)

finally yielding the inhomogeneous constant-coefficient second-order differential equation

mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=F(t)mu''(t) + \gamma u'(t) + ku(t) = F(t)mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=F(t)

Method (Second-order differential equation modeling of a physical system). The differential equation that governs the displacement of a spring u(t)u(t)u(t) over time is given by

mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=F(t)mu''(t) + \gamma u'(t) + ku(t) = F(t)mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=F(t)

where γ\gammaγ governs a damping force that is proportional to velocity u′(t)u'(t)u′(t), kkk governs a restoring force that is proportional to the displacement u(t)u(t)u(t), mu′′(t)mu''(t)mu′′(t) is the net force by Newton's Second Law, and F(t)F(t)F(t) is a variable external force.

Note that this equation makes several simplifying assumptions, namely that it assumes the restoring force is always under the limit of proportionality, that the resistive force is proportional to speed, and that the weight of the spring itself is negligible.

Undamped free vibrations

"Free" vibrations are ones where the external force F(t)F(t)F(t) is zero (as opposed to "forced" vibrations, which are forced to happen by the external force). If we suppose that there is no damping, then the damping constant γ\gammaγ is zero as well. This gives us the equation

mu′′(t)+ku(t)=0mu''(t)+ku(t) = 0mu′′(t)+ku(t)=0

which gives solutions

u=Acos⁡ω0t+Bsin⁡ω0tu = A\cos \omega_0 t + B\sin \omega_0 tu=Acosω0​t+Bsinω0​t

where ω02=km\omega_0^2 = \frac{k}{m}ω02​=mk​. We can conveniently rewrite this in the form u=Rcos⁡(ω0t−δ)=R(cos⁡δcos⁡ω0t+sin⁡δsin⁡ω0t)u = R\cos(\omega_0 t - \delta) = R(\cos\delta \cos \omega_0 t + \sin \delta \sin \omega_0 t)u=Rcos(ω0​t−δ)=R(cosδcosω0​t+sinδsinω0​t), as comparing coefficients obtains

{A=Rcos⁡δ,B=Rsin⁡δR2=A2+B2,BA=tan⁡δ\begin{cases} A = R\cos \delta, B = R\sin\delta \\ R^2 = A^2 + B^2, \frac{B}{A} = \tan \delta \end{cases}{A=Rcosδ,B=RsinδR2=A2+B2,AB​=tanδ​

From u=Rcos⁡(ω0t−δ)u = R\cos(\omega_0 t - \delta)u=Rcos(ω0​t−δ) we observe that the amplitude of the vibrations is RRR, the period is 2πω0\frac{2\pi}{\omega_0}ω0​2π​, the phase is δ\deltaδ (displaced δ\deltaδ radians rightward from normal), and the natural frequency is ω0\omega_0ω0​.

If no external force is applied, the system will continue oscillating without stopping, and will always vibrate at frequency ω0\omega_0ω0​ regardless of initial conditions (though the amplitude will be affected). The period is proportional to m\sqrt{m}m​ and inversely proportional to k\sqrt{k}k​, so larger masses vibrate more slowly and stiffer springs vibrate faster.

Damped free vibrations

In this case, the external force F(t)F(t)F(t) remains zero but the damping coefficient γ>0\gamma > 0γ>0. Our equation is

mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=0mu''(t) + \gamma u'(t) + ku(t) = 0mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=0

with characteristic equation

mλ2+γλ+k=0m\lambda^2 + \gamma \lambda + k = 0mλ2+γλ+k=0

yielding solutions

λ1,2=−γ±γ2−4km2m\lambda_{1, 2} = \frac{-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2 - 4km}}{2m}λ1,2​=2m−γ±γ2−4km​​

Thus, we will examine a few cases based on the value of γ\gammaγ.

  1. γ<4km\gamma < \sqrt{4km}γ<4km​. This is known as underdamping; the damping coefficient is very small, and the resistive force will also be fairly small in this case. As such, the solutions for λ\lambdaλ are complex with negative real part (γ>0\gamma > 0γ>0). We thus have

    u(t)=e−γ2mt(Acos⁡μt+Bcos⁡μt),μ=4km−λ22mu(t) = e^{-\frac{\gamma}{2m}t}(A\cos \mu t + B\cos \mu t), \mu = \frac{\sqrt{4km-\lambda^2}}{2m}u(t)=e−2mγ​t(Acosμt+Bcosμt),μ=2m4km−λ2​​

  2. λ=4km\lambda = \sqrt{4km}λ=4km​. This is the critical damping case, where the damping given ensures that the system returns to equilibrium in the shortest time. In this case, we write

    u(t)=(At+B)e−γ2mtu(t) = (At+B)e^{-\frac{\gamma}{2m}t}u(t)=(At+B)e−2mγ​t

  3. λ>4km\lambda > \sqrt{4km}λ>4km​. This is the \it overdamping \normalfont case, where the damping force is too large and the system returns to equilibrium slower than if critically damped. The equation gives

    u(t)=Aeλ1t+Beλ2t.u(t) = Ae^{\lambda_1 t} + Be^{\lambda_2 t}.u(t)=Aeλ1​t+Beλ2​t.

(Images courtesy of Dexter Chua. Thanks!)

These three cases each yield different forms of solutions for u(t)u(t)u(t), and each correspond to a different physical scenario. It is very important to note that in every case, the value of u(t)u(t)u(t) decays to 0 as t→∞t \to \inftyt→∞; this confirms our expectations that damping (resistive forces) would lead to the system gradually being pushed back to equilibrium.

In the latter two cases (critical and over-damping), no oscillations occur; in the underdamping case, however, the system does begin oscillating (though at a decreasing amplitude). Similar to the undamped case, we can rewrite u(t)u(t)u(t) for underdamping as

u(t)=e−γ2mt(Acos⁡μt+Bsin⁡μt)=Re−γ2mtcos⁡(μt−δ)u(t)=e^{-\frac{\gamma}{2m}t}(A\cos\mu t + B\sin\mu t) = Re^{-\frac{\gamma}{2m}t}\cos(\mu t - \delta)u(t)=e−2mγ​t(Acosμt+Bsinμt)=Re−2mγ​tcos(μt−δ)

for certain RRR and δ\deltaδ, with μ=4km−γ22m\mu = \frac{\sqrt{4km-\gamma^2}}{2m}μ=2m4km−γ2​​ being referred to as the quasi-frequency. Analogously, 2πμ\frac{2\pi}{\mu}μ2π​ is the quasi-period.

To examine the effect of underdamping on the system, let us compare the quasi-frequency to the undamped frequency ω0=km\omega_0 = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}ω0​=mk​​. We find that

μω0=4km−γ24km=1−γ24km≈1−γ28km\frac{\mu}{\omega_0} = \frac{\sqrt{4km-\gamma^2}}{\sqrt{4km}} = \sqrt{1-\frac{\gamma^2}{4km}} \approx 1-\frac{\gamma^2}{8km}ω0​μ​=4km​4km−γ2​​=1−4kmγ2​​≈1−8kmγ2​

where the final approximation is due to the binomial expansion, when γ\gammaγ is very small. Thus, the effect of underdamping is to slightly reduce the frequency of the system (and slightly increase the period). As γ24km\frac{\gamma^2}{4km}4kmγ2​ gradually approaches 0, the frequency approaches 0, transforming the system into one that is critically damped.

Forced vibrations

Forced vibrations occur when the external force F(t)F(t)F(t) is nonzero, producing an inhomogeneous second-order DE. Usually, this force will be an oscillating force of the form F(t)=F0cos⁡ωtF(t) = F_0 \cos \omega tF(t)=F0​cosωt where F0F_0F0​ and ω\omegaω represent the amplitude and frequency, respectively. This results in the following differential equation:

mu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=F0cos⁡ωtmu''(t) + \gamma u'(t) + ku(t) = F_0 \cos \omega tmu′′(t)+γu′(t)+ku(t)=F0​cosωt

which, assuming that the solution of the inhomogeneous equation is u=c1u1+c2u2u = c_1u_1 + c_2u_2u=c1​u1​+c2​u2​, yields the solution

u(t)=c1u1+c2u2+Acos⁡ωt+Bsin⁡ωtu(t) = c_1u_1 + c_2u_2 + A\cos\omega t + B\sin\omega tu(t)=c1​u1​+c2​u2​+Acosωt+Bsinωt

for some constants AAA, BBB. As shown in the above section, c1u1+c2u2c_1u_1 + c_2u_2c1​u1​+c2​u2​ decays to 0 as t→∞t \to \inftyt→∞; thus, we refer to uc(t)=c1u1+c2u2u_c(t) = c_1u_1 + c_2u_2uc​(t)=c1​u1​+c2​u2​ as the transient solution. As ttt grows larger, it will eventually become negligible in magnitude compared to U(t)=Acos⁡ωt+Bsin⁡ωtU(t) = A \cos \omega t + B\sin \omega tU(t)=Acosωt+Bsinωt, which persists indefinitely and is referred to as the steady-state solution or the forced response.

The transient part of the solution allows for any initial conditions to be satisfied. However, it vanishes very quickly compared to the steady-state solution.

Resonance

If our steady-state solution is rewritten algebraically as

U(t)=Rcos⁡(ωt−δ)U(t) = R\cos (\omega t - \delta)U(t)=Rcos(ωt−δ)

we are able to observe that its amplitude R=A2+B2R = \sqrt{A^2 + B^2}R=A2+B2​ is dependent directly on AAA and BBB, and thus dependent on the value of F0F_0F0​. Through algebraic manipulation it is possible to show that:

{R=F0ΔΔ=m2(ω02−ω2)2+γ2ω2ω02=km\begin{cases} R = \frac{F_0}{\Delta} \\ \Delta = \sqrt{m^2(\omega_0^2 -\omega^2)^2 + \gamma^2\omega^2} \\ \omega_0^2 = \frac{k}{m} \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​R=ΔF0​​Δ=m2(ω02​−ω2)2+γ2ω2​ω02​=mk​​

with ω0\omega_0ω0​ referring to the system's natural frequency. We observe that when ω→0\omega \to 0ω→0, R≈F0mω02=F0kR \approx \frac{F_0}{m\omega_0^2} = \frac{F_0}{k}R≈mω02​F0​​=kF0​​; and when ω→inf⁡\omega \to \infω→inf, R≈0R \approx 0R≈0. Between those two extremes, there may be a value of ω\omegaω that yields a maximum value of RRR; differentiation reveals that such a value ωmax\omega_{max}ωmax​ lies at

ωmax2=ω02(1−γ22mk)\omega_{max}^2 = \omega_0^2(1-\frac{\gamma^2}{2mk})ωmax2​=ω02​(1−2mkγ2​)

which only exists if γ22mk<1\frac{\gamma^2}{2mk} < 12mkγ2​<1; otherwise, RRR is monotonously decreasing. We observe that when γ\gammaγ is small, ωmax\omega_{max}ωmax​ is very close to ω0\omega_0ω0​, the natural frequency. This phenomenon is known as resonance: at or near the natural frequency, the amplitude of the oscillations reaches a peak. This can have both positive and negative consequences, such as amplifying vibrations produced by vehicles across bridges and potentially causing a collapse.
